subtitle: Sarah Arao Mantle of Hope- Thank You Video to the Y on Earth Community for GoFundMe Campaign Support
description: Thanks again to everybody supporting this YONERS community podcast as well as all of our community mobilization work around the country and internationally for climate action,
full_transcript:
[8.6s - 14.1s]: Welcome to the Y on Earth Community podcast. Today we have the opportunity to visit with Eric

[14.1s - 18.4s]: Lombardi. Hey, Eric. Good to be here, Aaron. Good to be with you today. Good.

[20.0s - 24.9s]: Eric Lombardi has been working at the cutting edge of the zero waste and social enterprise

[24.9s - 31.4s]: movements across the world since the mid-1990s. He was a national spokesperson for the first

[31.4s - 38.7s]: zero waste organization in the United States in 1997 and was a co-founder of the zero waste

[38.7s - 46.8s]: international alliance in 2002. Eric was invited to the Clinton White House in 1998 as one

[46.8s - 54.0s]: of the top 100 USA recyclers and received a Lifetime Achievement Award from the Colorado

[54.0s - 62.6s]: Association for Recycling. From 1989 to 2014, he turned a small nonprofit called Ecocycle

[62.6s - 69.7s]: into the largest zero waste social enterprise in the United States. Eric is now working as an

[69.7s - 75.8s]: associate to the social enterprise world forum and promoting hybrid business structures to

[75.8s - 82.2s]: achieve zero waste zero carbon communities. Eric holds a master's degree in technology

[82.2s - 87.9s]: and human affairs from Washington University in St. Louis. So Eric, it is such a joy to have

[87.9s - 93.3s]: this opportunity to visit with you today and we've got a lot to cover and of course you've

[93.3s - 98.3s]: had a long and really amazingly successful career during the work that you've been doing

[98.3s - 103.1s]: with zero waste and I thought I'd asked as a way to kind of kick things off, how did you

[103.1s - 109.3s]: get into all of this in the first place? Well, I've been at it for a while so we've got

[109.3s - 117.7s]: to go way back to the 1970s and I remember 1973 when we had the first oil embargo from

[117.7s - 123.6s]: Saudi Arabia and they cut America off and that kind of, I think I just got my first car

[124.2s - 129.1s]: and all of a sudden I couldn't get gas and I was not an environmentalist in 1973. I was

[129.1s - 133.9s]: a city kid in Denver and so that kind of blew me away. It's like, okay, what's going on

[133.9s - 139.8s]: here? And then for the next six years I did some world travel and I found out that I didn't

[139.8s - 144.6s]: know much about the world. I went overseas, Greece and Europe and then I came back in 79

[144.6s - 149.5s]: the next oil embargo hit and that's when I realized there's something very big and interesting

[149.5s - 156.0s]: going on here and I started studying solar energy, got my first solar job in 1980 and that's

[156.0s - 163.0s]: 50 years ago now I guess. And no, 40 years ago, okay, well, depends if you're around.

[163.2s - 168.8s]: That's right. Here's half century. So 40 years ago, got my first solar job here in Boulder,

[169.6s - 175.9s]: building solar analysis and then I went into water conservation work and then I went into

[175.9s - 181.0s]: waste recycling and that was basically about 35 year professional career.

[182.2s - 187.4s]: It's really interesting. I of course also have a some background in the waste in the recycling

[187.4s - 192.9s]: world and it's fascinating to me that there are a few of us in the country and in the world who

[192.9s - 197.5s]: know quite a lot about what's going on in the alleyways and with the dumpsters, with the things

[197.5s - 202.1s]: that are sort of out of sight, out of mind. But the truth is that most of us in America and

[202.1s - 208.6s]: probably most folks in other countries as well aren't probably thinking a whole lot about what's

[208.6s - 214.6s]: happening with things once we've discarded them and some would say that's therein lies part

[214.6s - 220.8s]: of the problem. And I'm just curious in this span of the four decades that you've been doing

[220.8s - 226.7s]: this work have you observed any change in you know perceptions, in awareness, in understanding

[226.7s - 234.7s]: in the general public? You know, the quick answer is yes. I think there's a lot more information

[234.7s - 241.3s]: and people are a lot more aware and that's the good side. The bad side is we had a flurry of

[241.3s - 249.4s]: activity and behavior change in the 90s but we haven't gone much further past the 1990s for the

[249.4s - 257.1s]: last 20 years. So yes, the awareness is higher but behavior change has not matched that level of

[257.1s - 264.8s]: intellectual connection. And what do you think is causing us to sort of stall out or in other

[264.8s - 271.5s]: words why after 30, 40 years of the recycling revolution aren't we further along? Great question

[271.5s - 278.7s]: and that gets right to the meat of what I want to talk about today because the house is on fire.

[278.9s - 287.1s]: Let's get the context corrected. The environmental problems that I encountered in the 1970s are not

[287.1s - 294.5s]: I think compared to what we're talking about today. And so we have to increase our level of concern

[295.2s - 299.7s]: appropriate to the level of threat and it's as high as it can get at this point. So why aren't we

[299.7s - 307.9s]: further? I think that first we have to define where are we going and then we can see why aren't we

[307.9s - 313.1s]: further on each of those things. And I after 40 years have framed the solution to one phrase

[314.3s - 320.7s]: Z3 zero carbon zero waste and zero population growth. I think that's the agenda from the 21st century.

[322.2s - 328.3s]: And so I've been in the trenches working with the zero waste zero carbon part of that phrase.

[328.9s - 333.8s]: I had not worked with zero population growth. Lots of other people are working at it but again

[334.4s - 339.9s]: we're not having great success there in some places what we need to. But I can talk about the

[339.9s - 347.8s]: zero waste zero carbon part of this and the challenge. So there is no lack of solutions. We

[347.8s - 355.4s]: my cohorts for the last 40 years and beyond have been working on solutions to waste and dirty

[355.4s - 363.1s]: energy for a long time. And so solutions are there. The problem now is political, economic,

[363.1s - 370.1s]: and social change. That's really where we're all getting stuck. And I do I have been fortunate to

[370.1s - 376.0s]: travel world for decades on these issues. And it's not just America that's stuck. The whole world

[376.0s - 381.7s]: is stuck. There's little pockets here and there where they're actually moving forward. And I

[381.7s - 388.1s]: won't I don't want to analyze that in particular but overall the bad trends are getting worse

[388.1s - 394.9s]: at a time when we have the solutions on the shelf ready to go. So we need to talk about why are

[394.9s - 402.7s]: the solutions being done. I think the easy quick solution is to say follow the money

[403.9s - 411.6s]: who's making money. That's what's happening. And capitalism is a very powerful economic system

[411.6s - 420.3s]: that is basically taken over the old planet. And lots of people are talking about how capitalism

[420.3s - 425.2s]: needs to be reformed right now. And that's a lot of fun because 40 years ago we couldn't we weren't

[425.2s - 430.0s]: allowed to talk about that. Now we get to talk about it. And I guess lecture business schools

[430.0s - 434.2s]: and the students are talking about the professors are talking about everybody's talking about how

[434.2s - 441.5s]: capitalism has to be made more kinder and gentler. I'm skeptical because the power of

[442.1s - 449.2s]: just as a pure economic system is really amazing. I call it like the tiger. It's this beautiful beast.

[450.2s - 455.1s]: So the beautiful beast needs to have a fence put around it or else it'll eat you. And we all

[455.1s - 460.9s]: know that. And so governments do a fair job of putting a fence around the capitalist tiger.

[461.9s - 470.5s]: But we the people are the ones who should be defining where that fence is, how high that

[470.5s - 476.0s]: tiger gets to roam is. So that's one of the things that we have to do is we have to understand that

[476.5s - 482.2s]: the limitations on unfettered capitalism are not well defined.

[483.5s - 488.6s]: I'd like to switch off. Don't know why. I think our lights are okay for the purposes of

[488.6s - 495.1s]: you know, I can turn you into a video. So we had a little act of God there as some people would like

[495.1s - 504.2s]: to say. Lawyer for him. Yeah. So anyway, so follow the money. Capitalism is this powerful force in

[504.2s - 511.8s]: the world. And so that sort of explains a lot of why we got where we are today. But how are we

[511.8s - 518.8s]: going to change it? Do we have to change capitalism? Okay, yes. And everyone's talking about that.

[518.8s - 526.7s]: But really what we need to do is we have to understand that communities, the politics of saving

[526.7s - 535.0s]: ourselves, our planet, the politics requires a new sense of community direction and decision-making.

[535.7s - 543.4s]: Such that we have permission to change where the fence is around the tiger. Yeah. Because right now

[543.4s - 548.3s]: the the tiger is calling the shots. The tigers basically controls everything and says

[548.3s - 552.0s]: where the fence will be and where the fence won't be. We have to switch that dynamics of

[552.0s - 556.1s]: the community saying, no, I want the fence sucked in a little tighter here. You know, and the

[556.1s - 563.1s]: tiger can't go there anymore. And when it comes to zero waste and zero carbon, the tiger is no

[563.1s - 571.4s]: longer allowed to produce massively wasteful items that can't be recycled composted or used

[571.4s - 577.5s]: or repaired. Okay. That sounds like most people say, yeah, that's a good idea. Well,

[577.5s - 584.0s]: implementing that is really tough. Okay. And then when it comes to energy, the tiger is no longer

[584.0s - 590.4s]: allowed to produce energy that emits greenhouse gases. Yeah. Okay. So everybody says, yep, that's

[590.4s - 594.8s]: right. That's what we got to do. Well, how are you going to move the fence in on that? So the tiger

[594.8s - 599.2s]: doesn't get to do that energy anymore. And that's where I talked about community power. I think the

[599.2s - 603.4s]: community has to intervene in a way that, you know, a lot of people shake their heads at this,

[603.6s - 612.4s]: but it's kind of like, what if the public owns the energy resources? What if the public owns all

[625.4s - 631.4s]: power and the control to place the fences around waste and energy activities. And then you let

[631.4s - 634.7s]: the private sector do their thing. You know, because you don't want business doing government.

[635.0s - 638.7s]: They're not or government doing business. They're no good at that. You know, business doing

[638.7s - 645.7s]: government either has a good slip. So, but you want government and the, which is nothing more than

[645.7s - 651.5s]: the community and the community working together saying, like city Boulder and Minneapolis and some

[658.3s - 665.4s]: 100% clean energy by 2030. And these goals are fantastically aspirational, technically possible,

[666.1s - 671.4s]: but social and politically impossible under the system that we're operating under right now.

[671.7s - 679.0s]: But if this climate emergency actually gets discussed as an emergency and the government

[679.0s - 685.9s]: and the community and in hand says, okay, all this waste now belongs to the public,

[692.2s - 696.9s]: goes to the landfill is going to cost five times more than it costs today, which by the way,

[697.4s - 703.6s]: we land filling in Colorado for about 20 bucks a ton, the same technology in Italy costs 240 a ton.

[703.6s - 710.8s]: Okay. So, it's all about policy and taxes and all that. So, but, you know, you need political will,

[711.0s - 717.5s]: you need community support to do that. So, I think that we're talking about, you know, intervening

[717.5s - 722.4s]: on the energy in the waste industries in a way that a lot of people say, that's communism stopped,

[722.6s - 730.5s]: you can't do that. No, it's not really. What it is is think of the toy industry. In America,

[730.5s - 737.6s]: you're not allowed to build a toy that might hurt a child. Is that communism? That's just common

[737.6s - 744.4s]: sense. Right? So, that's all we need to bring common sense to the table and say, no longer can we

[744.4s - 749.8s]: have dirty energy, no longer are we going to produce the stuff of our lives in a way that it gets

[749.8s - 755.2s]: landfillers and centurated at the end. It all has to be recycled, composted, repaired.

[755.7s - 762.0s]: Yeah, that's what it meant. There's a classical parable in the economics literature that goes back

[762.0s - 767.0s]: a couple hundred years, which is the tragedy of the commons. And in this use of this term,

[767.1s - 771.6s]: communism or common sense, it made me think of the commons themselves. And when it comes to things

[771.6s - 776.8s]: like pollution and how we're doing energy and how we're doing waste, it seems it's an issue of

[776.8s - 782.5s]: the commons and needs to be treated. That's such. Yeah. And that's one of the good things,

[782.5s - 788.3s]: I think the internet can help us as the species understand a newer understanding about what the

[788.3s - 795.2s]: commons are. And we need to stop monetizing the commons, giving financial value to everything.

[795.5s - 800.9s]: Because financial value is only one yardstick. You know, the triple bottom line has social

[800.9s - 806.9s]: community benefit, environmental benefit, and then monetary benefit. And that's the reform to

[806.9s - 811.5s]: capitalism that you're hearing people even like Black Rock and all these other big capitalists say,

[817.8s - 822.7s]: because the discussion is going on there are fantastic. And as a matter of fact, at least

[822.7s - 829.3s]: me to what I'm doing these days, I've evolved from in the trenches, zero waste work, zero carbon

[829.3s - 837.5s]: work to helping create business hybrids like social enterprise that can create a new market

[838.3s - 845.3s]: for how to bring the technologies out. And in partnership with communities and governments.

[846.1s - 850.8s]: And I'll give you an example in Scotland. Scotland's a leader in social enterprise right now.

[850.9s - 854.9s]: They're doing two things that are fantastic. One of them is whole communities in Scotland are

[862.3s - 865.9s]: then builds the windmills and they're owning their own community energy systems. Yeah.

[866.3s - 873.2s]: So that's like, you know, taking it ownership of it. The other thing they've done is Scotland

[873.2s - 880.3s]: around the waste issues, fascinating. They took a small nonprofit, a zero waste nonprofit that

[886.1s - 889.6s]: You're trusted by the government and you're trusted by the business sector because you have a

[963.1s - 968.6s]: And you'll be able to read about them. Is that dot? I don't know. Okay. I'll figure it out for the

[974.3s - 979.4s]: doesn't look very revolutionary. But if you're in deep enough in the industry, you'll realize how

[979.4s - 984.9s]: revolutionary it is that the government actually trusts them enough because you know, governments

[984.9s - 991.5s]: are risked. The private sector is risked taking. And that's where the two have a hard time working

[991.5s - 999.2s]: together. And so this third entity, this enabling institution called zero waste Scotland is listening

[999.2s - 1005.0s]: to both and helping them reduce their risk and helping them take the appropriate risks.

[1005.9s - 1013.1s]: And managing risk when you're doing social changes, the key. And I love this model of a third party

[1014.1s - 1018.8s]: organization. It doesn't even have a name yet. The concept I've been reading. I've been trying

[1018.8s - 1024.9s]: to find anybody else doing this. It needs a name. It needs a concept because this trust from both

[1024.9s - 1034.6s]: sectors for a body of an organization that has the intelligence and the bandwidth to be able to

[1034.6s - 1040.0s]: negotiate both risks side of it. Yeah. Maybe some just comes to mind real quick instead of tragedy

[1040.0s - 1044.7s]: of commons. It's trust of commons or commons trust or something like that that could get attached

[1044.7s - 1050.9s]: to the concept. You're absolutely right. The word trust plays here. Because you know, not only do

[1050.9s - 1056.5s]: we have to learn how to trust people again, we also have to learn how to share. So the simple

[1056.5s - 1062.3s]: concepts are going to get us through this challenging time learn right now. Because the other

[1096.5s - 1102.9s]: a lower return. Just let's stay in the game. Keep me in business. So that's a key here too is the

[1102.9s - 1109.0s]: trust thing and the sharing of the risk thing enables change to happen in the marketplace.

[1109.8s - 1114.5s]: And that's what's missing right now. You know, I'm so struck, Eric, and so much of this has to do

[1114.5s - 1122.0s]: with economics and not only the mechanisms of economics, but really the constructs and the

[1122.0s - 1127.8s]: belief systems that we've established around economics and what's considered to be normal and

[1134.2s - 1140.2s]: time of the Renaissance after the Crusades brought this massive influx of wealth into Europe,

[1140.2s - 1146.3s]: and particularly many of the Italian city states and public finance emerged out of that. So many

[1146.3s - 1152.6s]: structures that just need take for granted now as being normal. And I think one of the phenomena

[1152.6s - 1158.4s]: that play in our country in particular in the United States in particular is that we because we're

[1159.0s - 1164.3s]: an amalgamation of people from all around the world, we sort of have this collective amnesia

[1164.3s - 1170.9s]: when it comes to wisdom that goes back hundreds upon hundreds of years. And many of us are running
